title: 105_hr2185
content:
The "USDA Accountability and Equity Act of 1997" defines key terms like Department, Secretary, Assistant Secretary, and socially disadvantaged customer. It also addresses the conversion of county committees in Title I. Effective 90 days after enactment, section 8(a)(5)(B) of the Soil Conservation and Domestic Allotment Act is amended to require county committees to consist of 5-7 members, with a majority representing agricultural producers elected by the Secretary. The committee members, appointed by the Secretary based on recommendations from underrepresented groups, must follow civil service laws. The county executive director or designated person will also be subject to regulations set by the Secretary. The local committee, selected by the Secretary, is responsible for making loan determinations under credit programs administered by the Department of Agriculture, subject to the State director's approval. Conversion of nonfederal Farm Service Agency county committee employees to federal civil service status is addressed in Section 102. The curr_chunk discusses the amendment of regulations related to the selection and functions of committees under the Soil Conservation and Domestic Allotment Act. It also mentions the classification of regulations based on soil-depleting or soil-building practices. The curr_chunk discusses the conversion of permanent county and area office employees to Federal civil service appointments based on their years of service. The curr_chunk discusses the conversion of temporary county and area office employees to temporary Federal civil service appointments, subject to regulations and the discretion of the Secretary. The curr_chunk amends various subsections in the United States Code related to the employment of temporary county and area office employees as temporary Federal civil service appointments. The curr_chunk amends sections in the United States Code related to temporary Federal civil service appointments, with an effective date of 180 days after enactment. TITLE II--PROGRAM EQUITY

SEC. 201. ACCESS TO CREDIT. Section 373(a) of the Consolidated Farm and Rural Development Act (7 U.S.C. 2008h(a)) prohibits the Secretary from making a direct operating loan to a delinquent borrower, unless the borrower received a write-down under section 353 and the delinquency was due to uncontrollable conditions. The Secretary cannot provide a direct operating loan to a delinquent borrower unless certain conditions are met, such as no unsatisfied judgments, a 2-year period after a write-down, demonstrating fiscal responsibility, or pending liquidation of farm operations. The borrower must meet necessary requirements to prevent loan delinquency. The Secretary of Agriculture is appropriated $10,000,000 for leases or contracts to sell real property to beginning farmers or ranchers. Debt write-downs under the Consolidated Farm and Rural Development Act are not treated as income for tax purposes. SEC. 204. ACCESSIBILITY OF HOUSING LOANS. Amends the Housing Act of 1949 to allow applicants without credit history or poor credit history to be eligible for loans if they demonstrate financial independence. SEC. 205. EXPANSION OF ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY INCENTIVES PROGRAM for socially disadvantaged agricultural producers. Section 1241(b) of the Food Security Act of 1985 is amended to increase funding to $300,000,000 and allocate \1/3\ for socially disadvantaged farmers and ranchers. Section 1240G of the Food Security Act of 1985 is amended by removing subsection (c) regarding same-year payments for contracts in the Environmental Quality Incentives Program. SEC. 206. PROGRAM EQUITY FUNDING.

Amends Section 1447(b) of the National Agricultural Research, Extension, and Teaching Policy Act of 1977 to appropriate $15,000,000 annually to the Secretary of Agriculture for program funding.

SEC. 207. ADVISORY COMMITTEE TO STUDY LAND GRANT INSTITUTION FUNDING.

Establishes an advisory committee to study the equitable funding of land grant institutions. The Secretary will establish a bipartisan advisory committee to study funding for higher education institutions to ensure equitable support. The committee will have 5 to 25 members appointed by the Secretary, who will not receive compensation. The advisory committee members do not receive pay, allowances, or benefits. They will receive travel expenses and a quorum is one third of the members. The Secretary is the chairperson, and experts and consultants can be hired. Federal agencies can provide staff upon request. The advisory committee can detail personnel from Federal departments to assist in its duties. The committee has powers to hold hearings, take testimony, administer oaths, and obtain official data. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the committee. The advisory committee can obtain official data from US departments and agencies, use the US mails, and must submit a report to the Secretary within 9 months of appointment. The committee will terminate upon report submission. SEC. 208. Funding of outreach and technical assistance for socially disadvantaged farmers increased to $10,000,000 annually. SEC. 209. Funding for Extension Indian Reservation Program set at $8,000,000 per fiscal year. Funding of farm ownership and operating loan programs increased to $585,000,000 annually for direct loans, with $85,000,000 allocated for farm ownership loans and $500,000,000 for operating loans.
